title.narrative: Stretching civic space in conflict ASSN

description.narrative:
Oxfam#s CSO partners in South Sudan, Niger, Central African Republic and Somaliland have expressed an interest in a learning exchange about #what works?# in influencing for more inclusive, people-centred security. While diverse contexts, all have been affected byarmed conflict, and to differing degrees face challenges including insecurity and a lack of protection of civilians, as well restricted civic space. While civil society#s vital role in security sector reform processes is recognized by global and regional bodies and policy frameworks, our partners face obstacles to their participation in governance processes and dialogue.
Civil society and the international community must adapt and develop strategies to effectively influence in shrinking civic space. This is a priority area for learning and knowledge generation for Oxfam and our partners in the Strategic Partnership (SP) on Dialogue and Dissent with the Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
The African Security Sector Network (ASSN) and Oxfam#s Conflict and Fragility team will convene a two-day Learning Event Stretching Civic Space: Influencing on Inclusive Security. The workshop will bring together our partnersto exchange programmatic experience and share strategies to prevent the shrinking of # and even stretch # civic space to influence on inclusive security in conflict-affected contexts.

participating-org.narrative:
The African Security Sector Network (ASSN) was created at Elmina, Ghana, in November 2003 out of a recognition of the need to harmonise and facilitate the activities of the various African organisations working in the area of Security Sector Reform and Governance(SSR/G).
The principal objective of the network is to promote democratically governed and effective security for the peoples of Africa, and to enhance the capacity of African governments, security institutions, legislatures and civil society organizations to undertake and own Security Sector Reform (SSR) programmes and projects.
The ASSN has developed as a multidisciplinary network spanningacademics, think-tanks, CSOs, security practitioners (active and retired), legislators in defence and security committees, etc, with a pan-African character that enables experiences from different traditions of security organisation and practice (Anglophone, Francophone and Lusophone) to be shared.
The network derives its core strength from its diverse competencies and locations (which enable it to work for change from both within and without); from a capacity for internal debate; and an ability to engage a broad range of security actors (national, regional and international), as well as policy-and decision-makers.
Knowledge Platform Security and Rule of Law
